author: From staff and wire reports
title: Sports briefs for Monday, October 12
text:
Sports briefs for Monday, October 12 From staff and wire reports Pharos-Tribune IHSAA sets pairings for football sectionals 
The IHSAA on Sunday announced the football sectional pairings for the 2015 tourney, which begins on Oct. 23 for Class 4A, 3A, 2A and A, and on Oct. 30 for the larger 6A and 5A classes. 
Class A No. 2-ranked Pioneer will face a stiff challenge right out of the gate, visiting No. 6-ranked North White in Sectional 41. 
In Class 4A Sectional 20, Logansport will visit No. 8-ranked Leo. 
The following are first-round pairings involving PT-area teams. 
CLASS 4A SECTIONAL 20 
Marion (0-8) at FW South (1-7) 
Logansport (1-7) at Leo (7-1) 
FW Bishop Dwenger (7-1) at FW Wayne (0-8) 
New Haven (5-3) at Mississinewa (5-3) 
CLASS 2A SECTIONAL 34 
Bremen (3-5) at Rochester (3-5) 
Delphi (2-6) at Oak Hill (6-2) 
Wabash (6-2) at Cass (5-3) 
Manchester (2-6) at Winamac (6-2) 
CLASS A SECTIONAL 41 
Pioneer (8-0) at North White (8-0) 
S. Central (4-4) at S. Newton (6-2) 
W. Central (1-7) at Lake Station (0-8) 
Tri-County (2-5) at North Judson (7-1) 
CLASS A SECTIONAL 43 
Fremont (2-6) at Laville (6-2) 
N. Miami (1-7) at Culver (3-5) 
Southwood (5-3) at Triton (1-7) 
Caston (1-7) at Northfield (3-5) Worthington earns All-MIAA honors 
BATTLE CREEK, Mich. — A pair of Trine women’s golfers wrapped up All-MIAA honors as the Trine women’s golf team placed fourth in the final round of the MIAA Championship, held Saturday at Bedford Valley Golf Course. 
Amy Worthington of Logansport and Julia DeBelly of Sylvania, Ohio each earned All-MIAA Second Team honors. The honor was the third all-conference nod of each player’s collegiate career. Overall, Thunder golfers combined for a 334 to place fourth in the final round and lock up a fourth-place finish in the conference. Trine has earned a chance to compete in the MIAA National Qualifier in the spring. The team will have a chance to earn an automatic-qualifying berth in the national championships. 
Worthington fired an 83 in the final round to finish seventh in the conference standings. The senior finished with an 82 average in MIAA rounds. Worthington earned All-MIAA First Team honors the last two seasons and will wrap up her MIAA career with three all-league performances. US holds on to win Presidents Cup 
INCHEON, South Korea (AP) — The United States held off an inspired rally Sunday to win the Presidents Cup for the sixth straight time, this one decided by the final match. 
The Americans got the winning point from Bill Haas, the son of U.S. captain Bill Haas, who won 2-up over an emotionally distraught Bae Sang-moon. Bae needed to win the final hole for the International team to share the cup, but he stubbed a chip. 
The Americans won 15 1/2-14 1/2, the closest competition in 10 years. 
The tense final session was just what this competition needed, though it didn't feel that way to the International team. It looked like the International team had control until Chris Kirk holed a 15-foot putt on the 18th, and Anirban Lahiri lost the hole by missing a 4-foot putt.
